questions.question: What is the yield percentage of oxazolidinones when CO2 and aziridines undergo cycloaddition catalyzed by compound 1?
How does the introduction of ligand XN into compound 1 affect its catalytic ability for the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines?
questions.answer: It improves the catalytic ability by increasing the Lewis base sites, resulting in a 2.4 times enhancement of the yield.

questions.question: What is the effect of treating compound 2 with acid solution on its catalytic efficiency for cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines?
questions.answer: The catalytic efficiency increases, with the conversion of aziridines increasing from 61% to 99%.

questions.question: What structural feature of MOF 1 contributes to its high catalytic activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines?
questions.answer: MOF 1 has many open metal sites which act as Lewis acid sites, contributing to its high catalytic activity.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the Lewis acid-base sites in catalysts and the yield of oxazolidinones from different CO2 reactions?
questions.answer: The presence of Lewis acid sites can effectively promote the cycloaddition of aziridines, while Lewis base sites can accelerate the dehydrogenation of propargyl amines, affecting the yield of oxazolidinones.

questions.question: What is the significance of selectively regulating Lewis acid-base sites in catalysts for CO2 conversion reactions?
questions.answer: Selectively regulating Lewis acid-base sites can turn on/off the catalytic activity for different reactions, which is significant for efficient CO2 conversion.

questions.question: What happens to the catalytic efficiency of compound 2 for the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines when nitrogen-containing ligand XN is introduced?
questions.answer: The introduction of nitrogen-containing ligand XN into compound 1 to form compound 2 increases the Lewis base sites, which significantly improves the catalytic efficiency for the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines.

questions.question: How does the treatment of compound 2 with acid solution affect its catalytic performance in different CO2 reactions?
questions.answer: Treating compound 2 with acid solution partially eliminates the Lewis base sites, which increases the catalytic performance for cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines but decreases it for carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines.

questions.question: Why does compound 1 exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines but not in the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines?
questions.answer: Compound 1 has many open metal sites acting as Lewis acid sites, which are favorable for the cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines but lacks Lewis base sites necessary for the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines.

questions.question: What role does the nitrogen-containing ligand XN play in the catalytic activity of compound 2 for CO2 conversion reactions?
questions.answer: The nitrogen-containing ligand XN acts as Lewis base sites in compound 2, which are crucial for enhancing the catalytic activity in the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines.

questions.question: How does the selective regulation of Lewis acid-base sites in MOFs influence the synthesis of oxazolidinones from aziridines or propargyl amines?
questions.answer: Selective regulation of Lewis acid-base sites in MOFs allows for the optimization of catalytic activity for specific reactions, influencing the yield of oxazolidinones from either aziridines or propargyl amines by turning on/off the catalytic behavior.

questions.question: What is the impact of acid treatment on the Lewis acid-base sites of compound 2 and its catalytic efficiency for different CO2 reactions?
questions.answer: Acid treatment of compound 2 removes part of the nitrogen-containing ligands, exposing more Lewis acid sites and decreasing Lewis base sites, which improves catalytic efficiency for cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines but decreases it for carboxylation cyclization with propargyl amines.

questions.question: Is the yield of oxazolidinones from the cycloaddition of CO2 and aziridines using compound 1 higher than 90%?
Does the introduction of ligand XN into compound 1 decrease the Lewis acid sites?
Can compound 2 with increased Lewis base sites catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines more efficiently than compound 1?
Is the catalytic activity of MOFs for CO2 conversion reactions independent of the presence of Lewis acid-base sites?
Does treating compound 2 with acid solution increase its catalytic efficiency for both cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines and carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines?
Is the yield of oxazolidinones from the carboxylation cyclization of CO2 with propargyl amines using compound 2 higher than using compound 1?
Does the selective regulation of Lewis acid-base sites in MOFs allow for the turn-on/off of catalytic activity for different CO2 reactions?
